issue.title: Fix IntegrateRGBD example compilation
issue.body:
Compilation of Open3D failed for gcc-12 with:
```
examples/cpp/IntegrateRGBD.cpp:71:15: error: argument 1 null where non-null expected [-Werror=nonnull]
   71 |         fclose(file);
```

Since `file` is already `NULL`, we don't try to `fclose()` it.

## Type

-   [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

## Checklist:

-   [ ] I have run `python util/check_style.py --apply` to apply Open3D **code style**
    to my code.
-   [ ] This PR changes Open3D behavior or adds new functionality.
    -   [ ] Both C++ (Doxygen) and Python (Sphinx / Google style) **documentation** is
        updated accordingly.
    -   [ ] I have added or updated C++ and / or Python **unit tests** OR included **test
        results** (e.g. screenshots or numbers) here.
-   [x] I will follow up and update the code if CI fails.
-   [x] For fork PRs, I have selected **Allow edits from maintainers**.

comment.body: Thanks for submitting this pull request! The maintainers of this repository would appreciate if you could update the **CHANGELOG.md** based on your changes.

issue.title: How can I annotate cuboids for visualization?
issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched for [similar issues](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues).
- [X] For Python issues, I have tested with the [latest development wheel](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/getting_started.html#development-version-pip).
- [X] I have checked the [release documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/release/) and the [latest documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/) (for `master` branch).

### My Question

I am using `open3d.visualization.draw_geometries` to visualize a point cloud and some cuboids. I want to annotate the cuboid with some text. Is this possible?

issue.title: Difference between O3DVisualizer and Scene Widget
issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched for [similar issues](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues).
- [X] For Python issues, I have tested with the [latest development wheel](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/getting_started.html#development-version-pip).
- [X] I have checked the [release documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/release/) and the [latest documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/) (for `master` branch).

### My Question

I dont really understand the difference between O3DVisualizer and Scene Widget.

review.body:
Thank you for reviewing promptly @benjaminum ! I addressed the comments to the best of my ability. I have also included the example inside the python docstring as suggested, and checked it by compiling documentation. I am, however, not clear regarding the unit test as I could not find any unit tests for `RaycastingScene` - your help would be appreciated. Finally, I have expanded my original submitted function to also output `primitive_uvs` as this made sense. > *[Reviewable](https://reviewable.io/reviews/isl-org/Open3D/6442#-:-NhgH-6U3In2gtpB8VkG:byfibn5)* status: 0 of 3 files reviewed, 3 unresolved discussions (waiting on @benjaminum) ___ *[`cpp/open3d/t/geometry/RaycastingScene.cpp` line 553 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/isl-org/Open3D/6442#-NhQzE0u55gVdEXx-Hom:-NhgI3ho48uGlrdKZ1vM:b-896fix) ([raw file](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/blob/b80c5a90fddc33794616be51cd597dff6eca4e8f/cpp/open3d/t/geometry/RaycastingScene.cpp#L553)):*
Previously, benjaminum (Benjamin Ummenhofer) wrote…
Pass cumsum as const reference to avoid copy
Done. ___ *[`cpp/open3d/t/geometry/RaycastingScene.cpp` line 855 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/isl-org/Open3D/6442#-NhR-g4q-qq05SE4RerK:-NhgI6YDB2l_eQNewtBu:b-iyedk8) ([raw file](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/blob/b80c5a90fddc33794616be51cd597dff6eca4e8f/cpp/open3d/t/geometry/RaycastingScene.cpp#L855)):*
Previously, benjaminum (Benjamin Ummenhofer) wrote…
Isn't the temporary Tensor destroyed here and the pointer invalid?
Thanks for spotting! I have changed so it hopefully makes more sense. ___ *[`cpp/pybind/t/geometry/raycasting_scene.cpp` line 203 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/isl-org/Open3D/6442#-NhR07Wn9gVH5Y5Pctlv:-NhgIOpCDrZX9kyBiwDC:b-htmnud) ([raw file](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/blob/b80c5a90fddc33794616be51cd597dff6eca4e8f/cpp/pybind/t/geometry/raycasting_scene.cpp#L203)):*
Previously, benjaminum (Benjamin Ummenhofer) wrote…
I think it would be easier to use the result if the cumsum. It would be similar to here http://www.open3d.org/docs/release/python_api/open3d.ml.tf.layers.RadiusSearch.html where each query can have a different number of neighbors. @dmitrishastin what is your opinion here?
Apologies - I am running into trouble compiling the ML module on Windows. Would you be able to provide an example of `RadiusSearch` output for me to be more clear on your proposed alternative? Thank you!

issue.title: The vertices are redundant when loading a triangle mesh from stl file

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Not a build issue, this is likely a bug.

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched for [similar issues](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues).
- [X] For Python issues, I have tested with the [latest development wheel](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/getting_started.html#development-version-pip).
- [X] I have checked the [release documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/release/) and the [latest documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/) (for `master` branch).

### Describe the issue

When I tried to load a model(.stl file) by function o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh() and check its watertightness by funcition is_watertight(), unexpectedly getting "False" as a result, because my model which was generated by Marching Cubes algorithm is supposed to be a closed surface mesh. By further check on the mesh, I noticed that o3d seemed to believe the mesh has boundary edges. But when I loaded the model by VTK, this phenomenon disappeared. I found that the number of vertices in the mesh is different for the same model loaded by different IO functions (VTK has a much smaller number). So, I think there must be something wrong when o3d loading a .stl file, it cannot well merge the duplicate vertices.

### Steps to reproduce the bug

```python
import open3d as o3d
import numpy as np
import vtkmodules.all as vtk

filename = 'model.STL'

# load by o3d
mesh = o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh(filename)
mesh.compute_vertex_normals()
print("o3d vertex num:", np.asarray(mesh.vertices).shape[0])  # output 903836

# load by VTK
reader = vtk.vtkSTLReader()
reader.SetFileName(filename)
reader.Update()
print("vtk vertex num:", reader.GetOutput().GetNumberOfPoints())  # output 175772
```


### Error message

_No response_

### Expected behavior

_No response_

### Open3D, Python and System information

```markdown
- Operating system: Windows 11 64-bit
- Python version: Python 3.9
- Open3D version: 0.17.0
- VTK version: 9.1.0
- System architecture: x64
- Is this a remote workstation?: no
- How did you install Open3D?: pip
```


### Additional information

the test model link: [https://github.com/Amble12345/123/blob/main/model.zip](url)

comment.body: If the download url does not work, use this: [https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Amble12345/123/main/model.zip](url)

issue.title: The vertices are redundant when loading a triangle mesh from stl file

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Not a build issue, this is likely a bug.

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched for [similar issues](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues).
- [X] For Python issues, I have tested with the [latest development wheel](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/getting_started.html#development-version-pip).
- [X] I have checked the [release documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/release/) and the [latest documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/) (for `master` branch).

### Describe the issue

When I tried to load a model(.stl file) by function o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh() and check its watertightness by funcition is_watertight(), unexpectedly getting "False" as a result, because my model which was generated by Marching Cubes algorithm is supposed to be a closed surface mesh. By further check on the mesh, I noticed that o3d seemed to believe the mesh has boundary edges. But when I loaded the model by VTK, this phenomenon disappeared. I found that the number of vertices in the mesh is different for the same model loaded by different IO functions (VTK has a much smaller number). So, I think there must be something wrong when o3d loading a .stl file, it cannot well merge the duplicate vertices.

### Steps to reproduce the bug

```python
import open3d as o3d
import numpy as np
import vtkmodules.all as vtk

filename = 'model.STL'

# load by o3d
mesh = o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh(filename)
mesh.compute_vertex_normals()
print("o3d vertex num:", np.asarray(mesh.vertices).shape[0])  # output 903836

# load by VTK
reader = vtk.vtkSTLReader()
reader.SetFileName(filename)
reader.Update()
print("vtk vertex num:", reader.GetOutput().GetNumberOfPoints())  # output 175772
```


### Error message

_No response_

### Expected behavior

_No response_

### Open3D, Python and System information

```markdown
- Operating system: Windows 11 64-bit
- Python version: Python 3.9
- Open3D version: 0.17.0
- VTK version: 9.1.0
- System architecture: x64
- Is this a remote workstation?: no
- How did you install Open3D?: pip
```


### Additional information

the test model link: [https://github.com/Amble12345/123/blob/main/model.zip](url)

issue.title: How to identity all surface voxels from a VoxelGrid object effectively?
issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched for [similar issues](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues).
- [X] For Python issues, I have tested with the [latest development wheel](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/getting_started.html#development-version-pip).
- [X] I have checked the [release documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/release/) and the [latest documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/) (for `master` branch).

### My Question

I'm going to do a project by voxelizing a mesh object. One project step is to evaluate the voxel grid quality by surface voxels normals consistency. 

Actually, I created a function to filter surface voxels. But, the problem is that as the voxel size decreases, there is a sudden increase in the time spent on the procedure. I tried to optimize the function, but it didn't make significant work.

My old solution:
1. load the .stl file and convert it to a mesh object
2. create a voxel grid object based on the mesh with a size (0.1)
3. for each voxel in the voxel grid:
    3.1 locating the voxel index
    3.2 finding the voxel's neighbors index by a custom function (at first it would find all 26 neighbors, but now, it only find 6 neighbors)
    3.3 check if all neighbors' voxel index in the voxel grid, if any neighbor is in a "no record" state, then the voxel is a surface voxel


my [sample file](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-x90cyibmVRAgQ_yId3emHnnCZo6J0Vo/view?usp=sharing)

Below is my code:
```
import open3d as o3d
import numpy as np


# settings
sample_path = 'data/sample.stl'
voxel_size = 0.1

# custom function to generate a voxel's neighbors' index
def get_voxel_neighbors(index):
    x_neighbors_1 = index - [1, 0, 0]
    x_neighbors_2 = index + [1, 0, 0]
    y_neighbors_1 = index - [0, 1, 0]
    y_neighbors_2 = index + [0, 1, 0]
    z_neighbors_1 = index - [0, 0, 1]
    z_neighbors_2 = index + [0, 0, 1]
    return [x_neighbors_1, x_neighbors_2, y_neighbors_1, y_neighbors_2, z_neighbors_1, z_neighbors_2]


# get mesh
mesh = o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh(sample_path)
mesh = mesh.compute_triangle_normals()
total_triangles = len(mesh.triangles)
print('the mesh contains {} triangles'.format(total_triangles))

# create voxel grid
voxel_grid = o3d.geometry.VoxelGrid.create_from_triangle_mesh(mesh, voxel_size=voxel_size)
voxel_indices = get_voxel_indices(voxel_grid)
print(f'the voxel grid contains {len(voxel_indices)} voxels')

# get surface voxels
surface_voxels = []
for voxel in voxel_grid.get_voxels():
    score = 0
    index = voxel.grid_index
    surface_voxel = SurfaceVoxel(voxel_size=voxel_size, voxel_index=index, mesh=mesh)
    if surface_voxel.quick_check():
        neighbors = get_voxel_neighbors(index)
        for neighbor in neighbors:
            if isin_check(voxel_indices, neighbor):
                score += 1
            else:
                surface_voxel.add_surface_id(neighbor)
        if score != 6:
            surface_voxels.append(surface_voxel)
total_surface_voxel_count = len(surface_voxels)
print('surface voxel count:', total_surface_voxel_count)
```

comment.body: Yeah, that's why I created this issue. I need an effective method to identify all surface voxels. I found other packages, like VTK, that can tag surface voxel when the voxel grid was created, but they cannot cover my following analysis demands. So, I still tried to find an open3d solution

pull_request.title: Add RemoveDuplicatedTriangles feature using tensor API
pull_request.body: ## Type - [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue): Fixes # - [ x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality). Resolves # - [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected) Resolves # ## Motivation and Context This PR is an implementation of the RemoveDuplicatedTriangles but using the tensor API to be able to run it either on CPU or GPU (only CPU for now in this PR). This was also an opportunity to get familiar with the Open3D code. ## Checklist: - [x ] I have run `python util/check_style.py --apply` to apply Open3D **code style** to my code. - [x ] This PR changes Open3D behavior or adds new functionality. - [x ] Both C++ (Doxygen) and Python (Sphinx / Google style) **documentation** is updated accordingly. - [x ] I have added or updated C++ and / or Python **unit tests** OR included **test results** (e.g. screenshots or numbers) here. - [x ] I will follow up and update the code if CI fails. - [x ] For fork PRs, I have selected **Allow edits from maintainers**. ## Description Here is the note of my PR for the RemoveDuplicatedTriangles feture using Tensor API. The first problem of this feature is how to identify duplicated triangles. I keep the same solution than the Eigen based API RemoveDuplicatedTriangles that is to use a unordered_map that has a complexity of search in O(1) due to the use of a hash function. This unordered_map is implemented with a tuple as key instead of a tensor directly is because the hash function using a tensor is not implemented. So we have to "convert" a vertice tensor of 3 points to a tuple to be able to keep track of the triangle. The second problem is how to remove the duplicated triangles. I choose to iterate on the index of the unique triangles and to copy them in a new tensor I did this like that because we don't know the size of the new tensor of triangles until we have looped on all triangles. I have tried to use : tensor.reshape(), but it reshapes the tensor in a tensor with the same number of elements. tensor.append(), but we need it doesn't increase the size of the vector where we append elements. In the worst case where we have only one duplicated triangles we will need to iterate one time on the number of triangles and an other time on number of triangles - 1, so the complexity is in O(n*(n-1)) and in the best case O(n) due to the test if before the second loop. I have also treated the case if there are some normales triangles. I suppose that the number of triangles and normales triangles are the same and they are at a corresponding index. - - - This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/isl-org/Open3D/6409)

pull_request.title: Add RemoveDuplicatedTriangles feature using tensor API
pull_request.body: ## Type - [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue): Fixes # - [ x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality). Resolves # - [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected) Resolves # ## Motivation and Context This PR is an implementation of the RemoveDuplicatedTriangles but using the tensor API to be able to run it either on CPU or GPU (only CPU for now in this PR). This was also an opportunity to get familiar with the Open3D code. ## Checklist: - [x ] I have run `python util/check_style.py --apply` to apply Open3D **code style** to my code. - [x ] This PR changes Open3D behavior or adds new functionality. - [x ] Both C++ (Doxygen) and Python (Sphinx / Google style) **documentation** is updated accordingly. - [x ] I have added or updated C++ and / or Python **unit tests** OR included **test results** (e.g. screenshots or numbers) here. - [x ] I will follow up and update the code if CI fails. - [x ] For fork PRs, I have selected **Allow edits from maintainers**. ## Description Here is the note of my PR for the RemoveDuplicatedTriangles feture using Tensor API. The first problem of this feature is how to identify duplicated triangles. I keep the same solution than the Eigen based API RemoveDuplicatedTriangles that is to use a unordered_map that has a complexity of search in O(1) due to the use of a hash function. This unordered_map is implemented with a tuple as key instead of a tensor directly is because the hash function using a tensor is not implemented. So we have to "convert" a vertice tensor of 3 points to a tuple to be able to keep track of the triangle. The second problem is how to remove the duplicated triangles. I choose to iterate on the index of the unique triangles and to copy them in a new tensor I did this like that because we don't know the size of the new tensor of triangles until we have looped on all triangles. I have tried to use : tensor.reshape(), but it reshapes the tensor in a tensor with the same number of elements. tensor.append(), but we need it doesn't increase the size of the vector where we append elements. In the worst case where we have only one duplicated triangles we will need to iterate one time on the number of triangles and an other time on number of triangles - 1, so the complexity is in O(n*(n-1)) and in the best case O(n) due to the test if before the second loop. I have also treated the case if there are some normales triangles. I suppose that the number of triangles and normales triangles are the same and they are at a corresponding index. - - - This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/isl-org/Open3D/6409)

issue.title: How to identity all surface voxels from a VoxelGrid object effectively?
issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched for [similar issues](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues).
- [X] For Python issues, I have tested with the [latest development wheel](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/getting_started.html#development-version-pip).
- [X] I have checked the [release documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/release/) and the [latest documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/) (for `master` branch).

### My Question

I'm going to do a project by voxelizing a mesh object. One project step is to evaluate the voxel grid quality by surface voxels normals consistency. 

Actually, I created a function to filter surface voxels. But, the problem is that as the voxel size decreases, there is a sudden increase in the time spent on the procedure. I tried to optimize the function, but it didn't make significant work.

My old solution:
1. load the .stl file and convert it to a mesh object
2. create a voxel grid object based on the mesh with a size (0.1)
3. for each voxel in the voxel grid:
    3.1 locating the voxel index
    3.2 finding the voxel's neighbors index by a custom function (at first it would find all 26 neighbors, but now, it only find 6 neighbors)
    3.3 check if all neighbors' voxel index in the voxel grid, if any neighbor is in a "no record" state, then the voxel is a surface voxel


my [sample file](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-x90cyibmVRAgQ_yId3emHnnCZo6J0Vo/view?usp=sharing)

Below is my code:
```
import open3d as o3d
import numpy as np


# settings
sample_path = 'data/sample.stl'
voxel_size = 0.1

# custom function to generate a voxel's neighbors' index
def get_voxel_neighbors(index):
    x_neighbors_1 = index - [1, 0, 0]
    x_neighbors_2 = index + [1, 0, 0]
    y_neighbors_1 = index - [0, 1, 0]
    y_neighbors_2 = index + [0, 1, 0]
    z_neighbors_1 = index - [0, 0, 1]
    z_neighbors_2 = index + [0, 0, 1]
    return [x_neighbors_1, x_neighbors_2, y_neighbors_1, y_neighbors_2, z_neighbors_1, z_neighbors_2]


# get mesh
mesh = o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh(sample_path)
mesh = mesh.compute_triangle_normals()
total_triangles = len(mesh.triangles)
print('the mesh contains {} triangles'.format(total_triangles))

# create voxel grid
voxel_grid = o3d.geometry.VoxelGrid.create_from_triangle_mesh(mesh, voxel_size=voxel_size)
voxel_indices = get_voxel_indices(voxel_grid)
print(f'the voxel grid contains {len(voxel_indices)} voxels')

# get surface voxels
surface_voxels = []
for voxel in voxel_grid.get_voxels():
    score = 0
    index = voxel.grid_index
    surface_voxel = SurfaceVoxel(voxel_size=voxel_size, voxel_index=index, mesh=mesh)
    if surface_voxel.quick_check():
        neighbors = get_voxel_neighbors(index)
        for neighbor in neighbors:
            if isin_check(voxel_indices, neighbor):
                score += 1
            else:
                surface_voxel.add_surface_id(neighbor)
        if score != 6:
            surface_voxels.append(surface_voxel)
total_surface_voxel_count = len(surface_voxels)
print('surface voxel count:', total_surface_voxel_count)
```

comment.body:
@Carloszone I will check after my office, however, just pointing that your code is O(NumberOfVoxels) and when changing voxel size from 0.1 to 0.01, the number of voxels will increase by roughly 100, resulting in approx 100 times slower code.

The slowdown I noticed was approx 200 times. I will check in details tonight.

```
# voxel size 0.1
the mesh contains 11426 triangles
the voxel grid contains 22 voxels
surface voxel count: 14
Code block 'test' took: 34.81328 ms

# voxel size 0.05 - should slow approximately 4 times, but slows down by 2.5
the mesh contains 11426 triangles
the voxel grid contains 92 voxels
surface voxel count: 43
Code block 'test' took: 82.96480 ms

# voxel size 0.01
the mesh contains 11426 triangles
the voxel grid contains 2211 voxels
surface voxel count: 315
Code block 'test' took: 7508.77045 ms
```

issue.title: Request for minimal oriented bounding box for a given point cloud
issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched for [similar issues](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues).
- [X] For Python issues, I have tested with the [latest development wheel](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/getting_started.html#development-version-pip).
- [X] I have checked the [release documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/release/) and the [latest documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/) (for `master` branch).

### Proposed new feature or change

There are currently two functions that calculate a bounding box for a given point cloud:
`PointCloud.get_axis_aligned_bounding_box()` calculates the minimum axis-aligned bounding box w.r.t. to the lab frame, and `PointCloud.get_oriented_bounding_box()` calculates the minimum axis-aligned-bounding box w.r.t. to the coordinate system of the point cloud. Here, the coordinate system of the point cloud is determined via PCA. However, this is not necessarily the smallest bounding box of the point cloud. Other libraries already provide the smallest bounding box of a point cloud and it seems some Open3D users request it as well.

### References

previous discussion: [https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues/5417](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues/5417)
Wikipedia about bounding boxes: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_bounding_box](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_bounding_box)
implementation in different library: [https://github.com/compas-dev/compas/blob/main/src/compas/geometry/bbox/bbox_numpy.py](https://github.com/compas-dev/compas/blob/main/src/compas/geometry/bbox/bbox_numpy.py)

### Additional information

_No response_

issue.title: How to identity all surface voxels from a VoxelGrid object effectively?
issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched for [similar issues](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues).
- [X] For Python issues, I have tested with the [latest development wheel](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/getting_started.html#development-version-pip).
- [X] I have checked the [release documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/release/) and the [latest documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/) (for `master` branch).

### My Question

I'm going to do a project by voxelizing a mesh object. One project step is to evaluate the voxel grid quality by surface voxels normals consistency. 

Actually, I created a function to filter surface voxels. But, the problem is that as the voxel size decreases, there is a sudden increase in the time spent on the procedure. I tried to optimize the function, but it didn't make significant work.

My old solution:
1. load the .stl file and convert it to a mesh object
2. create a voxel grid object based on the mesh with a size (0.1)
3. for each voxel in the voxel grid:
    3.1 locating the voxel index
    3.2 finding the voxel's neighbors index by a custom function (at first it would find all 26 neighbors, but now, it only find 6 neighbors)
    3.3 check if all neighbors' voxel index in the voxel grid, if any neighbor is in a "no record" state, then the voxel is a surface voxel


my [sample file](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-x90cyibmVRAgQ_yId3emHnnCZo6J0Vo/view?usp=sharing)

Below is my code:
```
import open3d as o3d
import numpy as np


# settings
sample_path = 'data/sample.stl'
voxel_size = 0.1

# custom function to generate a voxel's neighbors' index
def get_voxel_neighbors(index):
    x_neighbors_1 = index - [1, 0, 0]
    x_neighbors_2 = index + [1, 0, 0]
    y_neighbors_1 = index - [0, 1, 0]
    y_neighbors_2 = index + [0, 1, 0]
    z_neighbors_1 = index - [0, 0, 1]
    z_neighbors_2 = index + [0, 0, 1]
    return [x_neighbors_1, x_neighbors_2, y_neighbors_1, y_neighbors_2, z_neighbors_1, z_neighbors_2]


# get mesh
mesh = o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh(sample_path)
mesh = mesh.compute_triangle_normals()
total_triangles = len(mesh.triangles)
print('the mesh contains {} triangles'.format(total_triangles))

# create voxel grid
voxel_grid = o3d.geometry.VoxelGrid.create_from_triangle_mesh(mesh, voxel_size=voxel_size)
voxel_indices = get_voxel_indices(voxel_grid)
print(f'the voxel grid contains {len(voxel_indices)} voxels')

# get surface voxels
surface_voxels = []
for voxel in voxel_grid.get_voxels():
    score = 0
    index = voxel.grid_index
    surface_voxel = SurfaceVoxel(voxel_size=voxel_size, voxel_index=index, mesh=mesh)
    if surface_voxel.quick_check():
        neighbors = get_voxel_neighbors(index)
        for neighbor in neighbors:
            if isin_check(voxel_indices, neighbor):
                score += 1
            else:
                surface_voxel.add_surface_id(neighbor)
        if score != 6:
            surface_voxels.append(surface_voxel)
total_surface_voxel_count = len(surface_voxels)
print('surface voxel count:', total_surface_voxel_count)
```

comment.body:
Thank you for the mention. I post my code below and ensure it is complete.

The sample file is tiny, so you can set the voxel_size to 0.1 and 0.01 then  compare the runtime of the two runs

```
import open3d as o3d
import numpy as np


# settings
sample_path = 'data/sample.stl'
voxel_size = 0.01


class SurfaceVoxel:
    def __init__(self, voxel_size, voxel_index, mesh):
        self.voxel_size = voxel_size
        self.voxel_index = voxel_index
        self.mesh = mesh
        self.center = mesh.get_min_bound() + np.array([voxel_size * (voxel_index[0] + 0.5),
                                                       voxel_size * (voxel_index[1] + 0.5),
                                                       voxel_size * (voxel_index[2] + 0.5)])
        self.voxel_min_bound = mesh.get_min_bound() + np.array([voxel_size * voxel_index[0],
                                                                voxel_size * voxel_index[1],
                                                                voxel_size * voxel_index[2]])
        self.voxel_max_bound = mesh.get_min_bound() + np.array([voxel_size * (voxel_index[0] + 1),
                                                                voxel_size * (voxel_index[1] + 1),
                                                                voxel_size * (voxel_index[2] + 1)])
        self.points = [self.voxel_min_bound, self.voxel_max_bound,
                       self.voxel_min_bound + np.array([0, 0, voxel_size]),
                       self.voxel_min_bound + np.array([0, voxel_size, 0]),
                       self.voxel_min_bound + np.array([voxel_size, 0, 0]),
                       self.voxel_min_bound + np.array([voxel_size, voxel_size, 0]),
                       self.voxel_min_bound + np.array([voxel_size, 0, voxel_size]),
                       self.voxel_min_bound + np.array([0, voxel_size, voxel_size])]
        self.voxel_surface_ids = []
        self.triangles = None
        self.triangles_normals = None
        self.triangles_avg_normals = None
        self.triangles_total_areas = None

    def add_surface_id(self, ind):
        self.voxel_surface_ids.append(ind)

    def quick_check(self):
        bound_box = o3d.geometry.AxisAlignedBoundingBox(self.voxel_min_bound, self.voxel_max_bound)
        sub_mesh = self.mesh.crop(bound_box)
        triangles_count = len(sub_mesh.triangles)
        return triangles_count


# custom function to generate a voxel's neighbors' index
def get_voxel_neighbors(index):
    x_neighbors_1 = index - [1, 0, 0]
    x_neighbors_2 = index + [1, 0, 0]
    y_neighbors_1 = index - [0, 1, 0]
    y_neighbors_2 = index + [0, 1, 0]
    z_neighbors_1 = index - [0, 0, 1]
    z_neighbors_2 = index + [0, 0, 1]
    return [x_neighbors_1, x_neighbors_2, y_neighbors_1, y_neighbors_2, z_neighbors_1, z_neighbors_2]


def get_voxel_indices(voxel_grid):
    voxel_indices = []
    for voxel in voxel_grid.get_voxels():
        voxel_indices.append(voxel.grid_index)
    return voxel_indices


def isin_check(arr1, arr2):
    for arr in arr1:
        if np.array_equal(arr, arr2):
            return True
    return False


# get mesh
mesh = o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh(sample_path)
mesh = mesh.compute_triangle_normals()
total_triangles = len(mesh.triangles)
print('the mesh contains {} triangles'.format(total_triangles))

# create voxel grid
voxel_grid = o3d.geometry.VoxelGrid.create_from_triangle_mesh(mesh, voxel_size=voxel_size)
voxel_indices = get_voxel_indices(voxel_grid)
print(f'the voxel grid contains {len(voxel_indices)} voxels')

# get surface voxels
surface_voxels = []
for voxel in voxel_grid.get_voxels():
    score = 0
    index = voxel.grid_index
    surface_voxel = SurfaceVoxel(voxel_size=voxel_size, voxel_index=index, mesh=mesh)
    if surface_voxel.quick_check():
        neighbors = get_voxel_neighbors(index)
        for neighbor in neighbors:
            if isin_check(voxel_indices, neighbor):
                score += 1
            else:
                surface_voxel.add_surface_id(neighbor)
        if score != 6:
            surface_voxels.append(surface_voxel)
total_surface_voxel_count = len(surface_voxels)
print('surface voxel count:', total_surface_voxel_count)
```

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched for [similar issues](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues).
- [X] For Python issues, I have tested with the [latest development wheel](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/getting_started.html#development-version-pip).
- [X] I have checked the [release documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/release/) and the [latest documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/) (for `master` branch).

### My Question

I'm going to do a project by voxelizing a mesh object. One project step is to evaluate the voxel grid quality by surface voxels normals consistency. 

Actually, I created a function to filter surface voxels. But, the problem is that as the voxel size decreases, there is a sudden increase in the time spent on the procedure. I tried to optimize the function, but it didn't make significant work.

My old solution:
1. load the .stl file and convert it to a mesh object
2. create a voxel grid object based on the mesh with a size (0.1)
3. for each voxel in the voxel grid:
    3.1 locating the voxel index
    3.2 finding the voxel's neighbors index by a custom function (at first it would find all 26 neighbors, but now, it only find 6 neighbors)
    3.3 check if all neighbors' voxel index in the voxel grid, if any neighbor is in a "no record" state, then the voxel is a surface voxel


my [sample file](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-x90cyibmVRAgQ_yId3emHnnCZo6J0Vo/view?usp=sharing)

Below is my code:
```
import open3d as o3d
import numpy as np


# settings
sample_path = 'data/sample.stl'
voxel_size = 0.1

# custom function to generate a voxel's neighbors' index
def get_voxel_neighbors(index):
    x_neighbors_1 = index - [1, 0, 0]
    x_neighbors_2 = index + [1, 0, 0]
    y_neighbors_1 = index - [0, 1, 0]
    y_neighbors_2 = index + [0, 1, 0]
    z_neighbors_1 = index - [0, 0, 1]
    z_neighbors_2 = index + [0, 0, 1]
    return [x_neighbors_1, x_neighbors_2, y_neighbors_1, y_neighbors_2, z_neighbors_1, z_neighbors_2]


# get mesh
mesh = o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh(sample_path)
mesh = mesh.compute_triangle_normals()
total_triangles = len(mesh.triangles)
print('the mesh contains {} triangles'.format(total_triangles))

# create voxel grid
voxel_grid = o3d.geometry.VoxelGrid.create_from_triangle_mesh(mesh, voxel_size=voxel_size)
voxel_indices = get_voxel_indices(voxel_grid)
print(f'the voxel grid contains {len(voxel_indices)} voxels')

# get surface voxels
surface_voxels = []
for voxel in voxel_grid.get_voxels():
    score = 0
    index = voxel.grid_index

    if surface_voxel.quick_check():
        neighbors = get_voxel_neighbors(index)
        for neighbor in neighbors:
            if isin_check(voxel_indices, neighbor):
                score += 1
            else:
                surface_voxel.add_surface_id(neighbor)
        if score != 6:
            surface_voxels.append(surface_voxel)
total_surface_voxel_count = len(surface_voxels)
print('surface voxel count:', total_surface_voxel_count)
```

comment.body: What is `SurfaceVoxel` class? Can you run your reproducable code on provided data file to ensure that the code is complete.

### My Question

issue.title: Remove Sphere, which is added after selecting a point using open3d.visualization.draw
issue.body: ### Checklist - [X] I have searched for [similar issues](https://github.com/isl-org/Open3D/issues). - [X] For Python issues, I have tested with the [latest development wheel](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/getting_started.html#development-version-pip). - [X] I have checked the [release documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/release/) and the [latest documentation](http://www.open3d.org/docs/latest/) (for `master` branch). ### My Question I would like to either remove or make the sphere which is automatically added after selecting a point using open3d.visualization.draw significantly smaller. The added sphere is too big as it makes me stop seeing other points. Also, I was wondering if there is a way of implementing selecting a point and getting its coordinates and index using open3d.visualization.gui.
